pyfsm package¶

Submodules¶

pyfsm.pyfsm module¶

pyfsm.py

Module for the management, representation, and analysis of finite state machines (FSM).

This module provides classes and functions to: - Define state machines. - Generate transition matrices. - Analyze connectivity and accessibility between all states. - Detect inaccessible or unreachable states. - Detect windowed state-cycles - Detect closed cycles

Author: Raul Alvarez Email: ralvarezb78@gmail.com Version: 1.0.0 Date: 2025-06-15 License: MIT

class pyfsm.pyfsm.fsm(history_len=10)¶

Bases: object

Represents a finite state machine (FSM). This class allows you to define states and transitions of an FSM, as well as retrieve basic information about its structure.

Variables:

  • history_len – Array length of past states history, in order to detect unintended loops.

  • parse_state – Regex expression to parse state machines.

  • tmatrix – Matrix form of state machine.

  • machine_transitions – list containing defined transitions.

  • true_transitions – vector containing transition conditions that are True

  • true_transitions_name – vector containing names of transition conditions that are True for debug purposes

  • entry-point – Initial state.

  • conditions – Dictionary that contains expressions or funcions of named transitions.

  • state – Current state.

  • states – Defined name of number-coded states.

  • dead_states – List of states that aren’t never reachable from entry point or initial state.

  • state_history – A list of present and previous states in order.

  • check_cycles – If True check for cycles provoqued by external conditions that are considered abnormal.

  • tsymbol – Current transition symbol, it can be ->, => or a comma. Once defined on first expression it can’t be replaced.

  • check_disjoint – If True check for disjoint transitions on defined state, if not, throws an error FSMNondisjoinctTransitions

  • warnings – If true, prints the warnings.

  • debug – If true prints debug messages.

add_condition(t: str, fcond: str | Callable[[...], bool]) → None¶

Adds function/expression evaluate named condition.

Parameters:

  • t (str) – String containing the name of transition described on state machine.

  • fcond (str, Callable[...,bool]) – function returning bool or string expression to evaluate which results on a boolean type

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

Examples

def test_fcn():

return a%7 == 0

f.add_condition(‘t0’, ‘a%10 == 0’) # Expression: evaluates a%10 == 0 f.add_condition(‘t1’, test_fcn) # Function: evaluates a%7 == 0

Note: Conditions must be unique for each transition, if one transition name is

repeated, this will throw FSMRedundantCondition exception. To change one condition function/expression, you must dele first with del_condition() method

add_transition(s: str) → None¶

Add state transition or define a state machine <state_0> <transition_symbol> <state_1> : <transition_identifier> Where:

state_0 : Is the name of present state transition_symbol : One of those symbols allowed to represent a transition {->|=>|,} state_1 : New state

Note

Once a valid transition symbol is chose, it must remains the same for all machine state definitions, otherwise compile() method will throw an Exception FSMInconsistentTransition

Examples

Valid state machine syntax:

f = fsm() f.add_transition(‘A => B : t0’) f.add_transition(‘B => C : t1’) f.add_transition(‘C => A : t3’) f.add_transition(‘D => A : t4’) f.add_transition(‘D => D : t2’)

This is also valid:

f = fsm() f.add_transition(‘A -> B : t0’) f.add_transition(‘B -> C : t1’) f.add_transition(‘C -> A : t3’) f.add_transition(‘D -> A : t4’) f.add_transition(‘D -> D : t2’)

As well as:

f = fsm() f.add_transition(‘A,B : t0’) f.add_transition(‘B,C : t1’) f.add_transition(‘C,A : t3’) f.add_transition(‘D,A : t4’) f.add_transition(‘D,D : t2’)

This is not valid:

f = fsm() f.add_transition(‘A => B : t0’) f.add_transition(‘B => C : t1’) f.add_transition(‘C -> A : t3’) # Transition symbol syntax inconsistency f.add_transition(‘D -> A : t4’)

Parameters:

s (str) – String containing the syntax describing state transition.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

compile() → None¶

Compiles the state machine. 1.- Get a list of total states 2.- Parses all transitions 3.- Creates FSM in matrix form 4.- Verifies the integrity of transitions (unused, non-defined) 5.- Calculates non-reachable / dead states from entry point.

Warnings:¶

warning_unused_transitions() : Transitions that are valid, declared, but unused. warning_dead_states() : If Dead / unracheable states found.

Exceptions:¶

FSMUnknownException : If non-defined or general faillure goes on. FSMInconsistentTransition : If The transition syntax is not consistent (different symbols used to)

return:

None

rtype:

None

del_condition(cond) → None¶

Deletes existing condition.

Parameters:

cond (str) – Existing condition to delete.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

detect_closed_cycle(max_len: int | None = None) → List | None¶

Detects if exists a closed cycles on state machine.

Parameters:

max_len (None (by default) or integer. If None is chosen, length equals to history states length.) – max length search on history

Returns:

List containing closed cycle.

Return type:

None if no cycles or list

detect_windowed_cycles(max_len: int | None = None) → List[List] | None¶

Detects cycles on a window.

Parameters:

max_len (None (by default) or integer. If None is chosen, length equals to history states length.) – max length search on history

Returns:

List containing list of cycles.

Return type:

None if no cycles or list

get_allPaths() → ndarray¶

Calculates accessibility matrix from state transition matrix M nxn: R = M+M^2+M^3+M^4+…+M^n

Return R:

Accesibility Matrix R[i,j], if stat j is reachable from state i, then R[i,j] > 0

Rtype np.ndarray:

nxn Square Matrix

printable_history() → str¶

Creates a printable history of states.

:return : History of states :rtype : str

printable_matrix(M: ndarray | None = None, none_as_zero: bool = False) → str¶

Pretty print (pandas like) of a viven matrix

verify_deadStates() → bool¶

Verifies if there are unreachable states from initial state. Note: The list of dead states is available on self.dead_states

:return : True if dead states are present :rtype : bool

async run_fsm(run_method_async: bool = True)¶

Runs FSM.
